questions.text: Which of the following is the second generation LMA?
questions.solution:
Supraglottic airway device (SAD) or extraglottic airway device, is a medical device that maintains upper airway patency during anesthesia or unconscious situation. It also allows for limited intermittent positive-pressure ventilation (IPPV), offers some degree of protection against the aspiration of gastric contents, and can be used easily especially because it can be inserted atraumatically by a low-skilled practitioner

There are different types and shapes of LMAs; however, almost all of them are categorized as either first and second generation LMAs, and recently invented the third generation LMAs.

  • First Generation SGA: Simple breathing tube, usually with some form of mask or opening at the larynx. Examples: Classic LMA, LMA-Unique, SureSeal LM, Cobra PLA, Laryngeal Tube Airway.
  • Second Generation SGA: In general, it has provision for gastric drainage, better sealing through a posterior inflatable cuff that improved protection against aspiration, in addition to integral bite block. Examples: Combi-tube, Pro-seal LMA, LMA-Supreme, I-Gel, LTS-D, Air-Q, Aura-Gain, Protector, LMA Gastro.
  • Third Generation SGA: Has dynamic sealing mechanism plus double suction ports, in addition to the characteristic of the second Generation. Examples: Baska, Elisha, and 3G LM.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B) Ambu LMA - Incorrect

Ambu LMA (AuraOnce, AuraFlex, AuraGain) includes both first- and second-generation devices, but the generic term "Ambu LMA" does not specifically denote a second-generation LMA. AuraGain, for example, is a second-generation LMA, while AuraOnce is a first-generation one.

Choice C) Intubating LMA (ILMA) - Incorrect

Also known as the LMA Fastrach, this is a specialized first-generation LMA designed to aid endotracheal intubation, particularly in difficult airway scenarios. It lacks a gastric drainage port, making it unsuitable as a second-generation device.

Choice D) Classic LMA - Incorrect

The Classic LMA is the first-generation prototype of all LMAs. It consists of a simple breathing tube and mask without features like a gastric drainage port or an improved sealing mechanism.

Key Takeaway:

LMA ProSeal is a second-generation LMA due to its gastric drainage tube, improved airway sealing, and integral bite block, enhancing airway protection compared to first-generation LMAs.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred volatile induction anesthetic agent in the pediatric age group?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane is a fluorinated ether.

Nonpungency and rapid increases in alveolar anesthetic concentration make sevoflurane an excellent choice for smooth and rapid inhalation inductions in pediatric and adult patients.

In fact, inhalation induction with 4% to 8% sevoflurane in a 50% mixture of nitrous oxide and oxygen can be achieved within 1 min.

Likewise, its low blood solubility results in a rapid fall in alveolar anesthetic concentration upon discontinuation and a more rapid emergence compared with Isoflurane.

Sevoflurane produces the least respiratory depression among all the volatile agents, is less likely to irritate the airway or cause breath holding or laryngospasm than other agents and there are no reported instances of renal toxicity due to fluoride production during sevoflurane anaesthesia in children.

Hence, sevoflurane is the preferred agent for inhaled induction in pediatric anaesthesia.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B) Desflurane - Incorrect

  • Highly pungent, causing airway irritation, coughing, laryngospasm, and increased secretions, making it unsuitable for inhalational induction in children.
  • High vapor pressure requires a specialized heated vaporizer, limiting its use in pediatric induction.

Choice C) Halothane - Incorrect

  • Used historically for pediatric induction due to pleasant odor and smooth induction but has been largely replaced by sevoflurane due to its higher risk of cardiac arrhythmias and hepatotoxicity (halothane hepatitis).
  • Slower induction and emergence due to higher blood solubility.

Choice D) Isoflurane - Incorrect

  • Highly pungent, causing airway irritation, breath-holding, and coughing, making it unsuitable for inhalation induction in children.
  • Slower onset compared to sevoflurane due to higher blood-gas solubility.

Key Takeaway:

Sevoflurane is the preferred volatile anesthetic for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its non-pungency, rapid induction, minimal airway irritation, and quick emergence.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the incorrect step in the ideal sequence for effective CPR?
questions.solution:
To perform chest compressions in the unresponsive or pulseless patient, the xiphoid process is located, and the heel of the rescuer's hand is placed over the lower half of the sternum. The other hand is placed over the hand on the sternum with the fingers either interlaced or extended, but off the chest.

The rescuer's shoulders should be positioned directly over the hands with the elbows locked into position and arms extended so that the weight of the upper body is used for compressions.

With a straight downward thrust, the sternum is depressed approximately 2 inches (5 cm) in adults and1 to 1 1/2 inches (2-4 cm) in children and then allowed to return to its normal position. For an infant, compressions 1/2 to 1 inches (1 1/2-2 1/2 cm) in depth are made with the middle and ring fingers on the sternum one finger-breadth below the nipple line. Compression and release times should be equal.

Whether adult resuscitation is performed by a single rescuer or by two rescuers, two breaths are administered every 30 compressions (30:2), allowing 3 to 4 s for the two breaths. The cardiac compression rate should be 100/min regardless of the number of rescuers. A slightly higher compression rate of more than 100/min is suggested for infants, with two breaths delivered every 30 compressions.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

A) 100-120 rate per minute - Correct

  • The recommended compression rate for CPR is 100-120 compressions per minute for all age groups.
  • A rate below 100/min reduces perfusion, while exceeding 120/min may compromise chest recoil.

C) Compression to ventilation ratio is 30:2 - Correct

  • The standard compression-to-ventilation ratio for adult CPR (single or two rescuers) is 30:2.
  • In pediatric resuscitation, the ratio remains 30:2 for a single rescuer, but for two rescuers, it is 15:2.

D) Adequate chest recoil - Correct

  • Full chest recoil is crucial for venous return and effective cardiac output.
  • Incomplete recoil reduces cardiac filling, leading to decreased blood flow.

Key Takeaway:

The correct compression depth in adults is 5 cm (2 inches). A 3-4 cm depth is inadequate, making Option B incorrect.

questions.text: Patient was planned for surgery under general anesthesia, in the induction phase rocuronium was given, but the anesthetist did not succeed in intubating. Hence, which could be the best reversal agent used
questions.solution:
Sugammadex has been administered in doses of 4 to 8 mg/kg. With an injection of 8 mg/kg, given 3 min after administration of 0.6 mg/kg of rocuronium, recovery of train of-four ratio to 0.9 was observed within 2 min.

It produces a rapid and effective reversal of both shallow and profound rocuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade in a consistent manner.

Sugammadex is most effective in the reversal of rocuronium; however, it will bind other steroidal neuromuscular blockers, including vecuronium and pancuronium. Sugammadex is not effective in reversing nondepolarizing neuromuscular blockade secondary to benzylisoquinoline relaxants such as cisatracurium.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A) Neostigmine - Incorrect

  • Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that gradually increases acetylcholine to counteract neuromuscular blockade.
  • It is not effective in reversing profound blockade and is slower than sugammadex.

Choice B) Edrophonium - Incorrect

  • Another acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but its reversal effect is weaker and shorter-acting than neostigmine.
  • Not suitable for profound blockade or rapid reversal.

Choice D) Glycopyrrolate - Incorrect

  • An anticholinergic agent, not a reversal drug for neuromuscular blockade.
  • Often co-administered with neostigmine to counteract muscarinic side effects.

Key Takeaway:

Sugammadex is the best reversal agent for rocuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade, offering rapid and effective recovery, especially in failed intubation scenarios.

questions.text: Which of the following is the intravenous fluid of choice for pediatric patients?
questions.solution:
A non glucose containing solution such as Ringer lactate is administered to healthy children commonly.

1% or 2.5% glucose in RL is recommended for pediatric patients under 6 months of age and for young children who are cachetic, chronically malnourished, tolerate fasting poorly, and suffer from debilitating disease who may be at risk for hypoglycemia.

Routine use of glucose containing hypotonic solutions was discontinued due to association with perioperative seizures, aspiration and brain damage after large volumes were administered during surgery.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A) Normal Saline and Dextrose - Incorrect

  • 9% Normal Saline (NS) lacks buffering capacity and can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with prolonged use.
  • Not the first choice unless in specific cases like trauma, shock, or severe dehydration.

Choice B) N/5 and Dextrose - Incorrect

  • N/5 (0.18% NaCl) is a hypotonic fluid, which is not recommended due to the risk of hyponatremia, cerebral edema, and seizures, especially in surgical or critically ill children.

Choice C) N/25 and Dextrose - Incorrect

  • N/25 (0.09% NaCl) is even more hypotonic, carrying an even greater risk of hyponatremia and neurological complications.

Key Takeaway:

Ringer Lactate is the IV fluid of choice for pediatric patients, with added dextrose in those at risk of hypoglycemia(e.g., infants, malnourished children).

choices.text: Self-Inflating bag mask given close to mouth and nose
Flow bag with mask given close to mouth and nose
Tubing connecting oxygen supply close to mouth and nose
Mask is connected with oxygen supply close to mouth and nose

questions.text: All are acceptable method of free flow oxygen delivery system except
questions.solution:
Free-flow oxygen is recommended for newly born infants who are breathing but have central cyanosis.

There are a variety of devices which are available to provide free-flow oxygen. These include: a flow-inflating bag and mask, face mask, funnel, T-piece resuscitator and oxygen tubing held in a cupped hand close to the infant's face.

Incorrect Choices Explanation (Acceptable Methods):

Choice A) Self-Inflating Bag Mask Given Close to Mouth and Nose - Correct Method

  • A self-inflating bag can provide free-flow oxygen if held close to the infant's face without pressing on the mask.
  • Ensures higher oxygen concentration than tubing alone.

Choice B) Flow Bag with Mask Given Close to Mouth and Nose - Correct Method

  • A flow-inflating bag (or anesthesia bag) can deliver free-flow oxygen when connected to an oxygen source.
  • Requires a good seal for effective oxygenation but can also be used in an open system.

Choice D) Mask Connected with Oxygen Supply Close to Mouth and Nose - Correct Method

  • An oxygen mask connected to a flowing oxygen source can effectively provide free-flow oxygen to neonates.
  • The mask should be held close to the nose and mouth without sealing to allow spontaneous breathing.

Key Takeaway:

Free-flow oxygen should be delivered using appropriate devices like a self-inflating bag, flow-inflating bag, or oxygen mask.

Oxygen tubing alone is not a reliable method due to inadequate oxygen concentration delivery.
